title: Trump officials don't know where he got Baghdadi 'whimpering' details
text:
Trump officials say they have no idea where the President got his information that ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi died 'crying and whimpering'.

President Trump revealed news of the ISIS leader's death in a national address from the White House on Sunday morning as he provided graphic details of Baghdadi's final moments at the helm of the militant organization.

Trump watched the raid in real time from the Situation Room via a video link on Saturday night as troops blasted into Baghdadi's Syrian hideout and sent the most-wanted militant running the last steps of his life.

He described it playing out live 'as though you were watching a movie'.

As American troops bore down on Baghdadi, he fled into a 'dead-end' tunnel with three of his children, Trump said, and detonated a suicide vest, killing himself and the children.

Trump described Baghdadi as 'whimpering and crying and screaming all the way' to his death.

Trump officials say they have no idea where the President got his information that ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi died 'crying and whimpering'

'He was a sick and depraved man and now he's gone,' Trump said. 'He died like a dog, he died like a coward.'

But questions have since been raised about Trump's vivid description of Baghdadi's death, including how he knew that the ISIS leader was 'crying and whimpering' given there was no audio on the livestream he was watching.

Several senior Trump administration officials told the Daily Beast they don't know where the President got those specific details from.

Two of them said they immediately began messaging each other after Trump's address saying 'uh where is he getting that?'.

Officials said it was possible that Trump may have spoken to the commandos who were on the ground in Syria for the raid but that had not been in the case in past operations.

The country's top military officer, Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Mark Milley, also said on Monday that he didn't know where Trump got his details from when he faced repeated questions from reporters.

'I know the president had planned to talk down to the unit and unit members,' General Milley said.

'But I don't know what the source of that was. I assume it was talking directly to unit and unit members.'

Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi (above) blew himself up after being cornered by U.S forces in a dead-end underground tunnel in his Syrian compound

Trump watched the raid unfold from the situation room. He was joined by National Security Advisor Robert C. O'Brien, Vice President Mike Pence, Secretary of Defense Dr. Mark T. Esper and United States Army General Mark A. Milley

General Milley said he had not spoken with unit members on the ground so he did not have firsthand knowledge of those details.

Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper gave a similar response when asked if he, like Trump, had heard whimpering and crying.

'I don't have those details,' Esper said.

'The president probably had the opportunity to talk to the commanders on the ground.'

A source close to Trump has said it is one of the President's favorite insults to accuse his enemies of 'being weak and just crying all over the place'.

The daring raid on the compound where Baghdadi was hiding in Syria was the culmination of years of steady intelligence-gathering work - and 48 hours of hurry-up planning once Washington got word on where he would be.

Trump had teased a major announcement late Saturday, tweeting that 'something very big has just happened!' By the morning, he was thanking Russia, Turkey, Syria and Iraq, as well as Kurdish fighters in Syria for their support.

The operation marks a significant foreign policy success for Trump, coming at one of the lowest points in his presidency as he is mired in impeachment proceedings and facing widespread Republican condemnation for his Syria policy.

The daring raid on the compound (above) where Baghdadi was hiding in Syria was the culmination of years of steady intelligence-gathering work - and 48 hours of hurry-up planning once Washington got word on where he would be

Al-Baghdadi, the leader of the so-called Islamic caliphate, blew himself up during the targeted attack on his lair in Syria's Idlib province in the early hours of Sunday morning. His lair was in a village known for smuggling, and he arrived there 48 hours before the raid

The recent pullback of U.S. troops he ordered from northeastern Syria raised a storm of bipartisan criticism in Washington that the militant group could regain strength after it had lost vast stretches of territory it had once controlled.

Planning for the operation began weeks ago, Trump said, after the U.S. gained unspecified intelligence on Baghdadi's whereabouts.

Eight military helicopters flew for more than an hour over territory controlled by Russian and Syrian forces, Trump said, before landing under gunfire at the compound.

Trump vividly described the raid and took extensive questions from reporters for more than 45 minutes Sunday.

He said U.S. forces breached the walls of the building because the doors were booby-trapped and chased Baghdadi into the tunnel, which partially collapsed after Baghdadi detonated the suicide vest.

Trump also revealed that U.S. forces spent roughly two hours on the ground collecting valuable intelligence.

He went on to suggest that the killing of Baghdadi was more significant than the 2011 operation ordered by his predecessor, President Barack Obama, that killed al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden, who was responsible for the 9/11 attacks.
description: Trump officials say they have no idea where the President got his information that ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi died 'crying and whimpering'.
